column5: of the conquest by the European whites of a certain portion of Africa
column6: an impression in particular of the civilising methods of a certain great European Trading Company face to face with the ‘nigger.’ We say this much because the English reader likes to know where he is going before he takes art seriously
column7: and we add that he will find the human life
column9: in ‘Heart of Darkness’ an uncommonly and uncannily serious affair. If the ordinary reader
column11: insists on taking the subject of a tale very seriously
column12: the artist takes his method of presentation more seriously still
column13: and rightly so. For the art of ‘Heart of Darkness’—as in every psychological masterpiece—lies in the relation of the things of the spirit to the things of the flesh
column14: of the invisible life to the visible
column15: of the sub-conscious life within us
column18: feelings and outlook. Just as landscape art implies the artist catching the exact relation of a tree to the earth from which it springs
column19: and of the earth to the sky
column20: so the art of ‘Heart of Darkness’ implies the catching of infinite shades of the white man’s uneasy
column22: and fantastic relations with the exploited barbarism of Africa; it implies the acutest analysis of the deterioration of the white man’s morale
column23: when he is let loose from European restraint
column24: and planted down in the tropics as an ‘emissary of light’ armed to the teeth
column25: to make trade profits out of the ‘subject races.’ The weirdness
column27: the psychological truth of this masterly analysis of two Continents in conflict
column28: of the abysmal gulf between the white man’s system and the black man’s comprehension of its results
column29: is conveyed in a rapidly rushing narrative which calls for close attention on the reader’s part. But the attention once surrendered
column30: the pages of the narrative are as enthralling as the pages of Dostoevsky’s Crime and Punishment. The stillness of the sombre African forests
column34: of night on the tropical rivers
column36: degenerating whites staring all day and every day at the Heart of Darkness which is alike meaningless and threatening to their own creed and conceptions of life
column37: the helpless bewilderment of the unhappy savages in the grasp of their flabby and rapacious conquerors—all this is a page torn from the life of the Dark Continent—a page which has been hitherto carefully blurred and kept away from European eyes. There is no ‘intention’ in the story
column39: no prejudice one way or the other; it is simply a piece of art
column41: and the artist is but intent on presenting his sensations in that sequence and arrangement whereby the meaning or the meaninglessness of the white man in uncivilised Africa can be felt in its really significant aspects. If the story is too strong meat for the ordinary reader
column43: ’ wherein the song of every man’s youth is indeed sung. […] Mr. Conrad is easily among the first writers of to-day. His special individual gift
column45: is of so placing a whole scene before the reader that the air
column53: all fuse in the perfect and dream-like illusion of an unforgettable reality."|"Heart of Darkness and the Congo Diary"|"Joseph Conrad"

column1: ~ 03:00|"About three in the morning"|"“Towards the evening of the second day we judged ourselves about eight miles from Kurtz’s station. I wanted to push on; but the manager looked grave
column2: and told me the navigation up there was so dangerous that it would be advisable
column3: the sun being very low already
column4: to wait where we were till next morning. Moreover
column5: he pointed out that if the warning to approach cautiously were to be followed
column6: we must approach in daylight—not at dusk
column7: or in the dark. This was sensible enough. Eight miles meant nearly three hours’ steaming for us
column8: and I could also see suspicious ripples at the upper end of the reach. Nevertheless
column9: I was annoyed beyond expression at the delay
column11: since one night more could not matter much after so many months. As we had plenty of wood
column13: I brought up in the middle of the stream. The reach was narrow
column15: with high sides like a railway cutting. The dusk came gliding into it long before the sun had set. The current ran smooth and swift
column16: but a dumb immobility sat on the banks. The living trees
column17: lashed together by the creepers and every living bush of the undergrowth
column18: might have been changed into stone
column20: to the lightest leaf. It was not sleep—it seemed unnatural
column21: like a state of trance. Not the faintest sound of any kind could be heard. You looked on amazed
column22: and began to suspect yourself of being deaf—then the night came suddenly
column23: and struck you blind as well. About three in the morning some large fish leaped
column24: and the loud splash made me jump as though a gun had been fired. When the sun rose there was a white fog
column26: and more blinding than the night. It did not shift or drive; it was just there
column27: standing all round you like something solid. At eight or nine
column29: it lifted as a shutter lifts. We had a glimpse of the towering multitude of trees
column31: with the blazing little ball of the sun hanging over it—all perfectly still—and then the white shutter came down again
column33: as if sliding in greased grooves. I ordered the chain
column34: which we had begun to heave in
column35: to be paid out again. Before it stopped running with a muffled rattle
column39: soared slowly in the opaque air. It ceased. A complaining clamour
column41: filled our ears. The sheer unexpectedness of it made my hair stir under my cap. I don’t know how it struck the others: to me it seemed as though the mist itself had screamed
column43: and apparently from all sides at once
column44: did this tumultuous and mournful uproar arise. It culminated in a hurried outbreak of almost intolerably excessive shrieking
column46: leaving us stiffened in a variety of silly attitudes
column47: and obstinately listening to the nearly as appalling and excessive silence. ‘Good God! What is the meaning——?’ stammered at my elbow one of the pilgrims—a little fat man
column48: with sandy hair and red whiskers
column50: and pink pyjamas tucked into his socks. Two others remained open-mouthed a whole minute
column51: then dashed into the little cabin
column52: to rush out incontinently and stand darting scared glances
column53: with Winchesters12 at ‘ready’ in their hands. What we could see was just the steamer we were on
column54: her outlines blurred as though she had been on the point of dissolving
column55: and a misty strip of water
column57: around her—and that was all. The rest of the world was nowhere
column58: as far as our eyes and ears were concerned. Just nowhere. Gone
column59: disappeared; swept off without leaving a whisper or a shadow behind."|"Heart of Darkness and the Congo Diary"|"Joseph Conrad"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"“I laid the ghost of his gifts at last with a lie
column2: ” he began suddenly. “Girl! What? Did I mention a girl? Oh
column3: she is out of it—completely. They—the women I mean—are out of it—should be out of it. We must help them to stay in that beautiful world of their own
column5: she had to be out of it. You should have heard the disinterred body of Mr Kurtz saying
column6: ‘My Intended.’ You would have perceived directly then how completely she was out of it. And the lofty frontal bone of Mr Kurtz! They say the hair goes on growing19 sometimes
column8: was impressively bald. The wilderness had patted him on the head
column11: it was like a ball—an ivory ball; it had caressed him
column12: and—lo!—he had withered; it had taken him
column17: and sealed his soul to its own by the inconceivable ceremonies of some devilish initiation. He was its spoiled and pampered favourite. Ivory? I should think so. Heaps of it
column18: stacks of it. The old mud shanty was bursting with it. You would think there was not a single tusk left either above or below ground in the whole country. ‘Mostly fossil
column19: ’ the manager had remarked disparagingly. It was no more fossil than I am; but they call it fossil when it is dug up. It appears these niggers do bury the tusks sometimes—but evidently they couldn’t bury this parcel deep enough to save the gifted Mr Kurtz from his fate. We filled the steamboat with it
column20: and had to pile a lot on the deck. Thus he could see and enjoy as long as he could see
column21: because the appreciation of this favour had remained with him to the last. You should have heard him say
column27: my——’ Everything belonged to him. It made me hold my breath in expectation of hearing the wilderness burst into a prodigious peal of laughter that would shake the fixed stars in their places. Everything belonged to him—but that was a trifle. The thing was to know what he belonged to
column28: how many powers of darkness claimed him for their own. That was the reflection that made you creepy all over. It was impossible—it was not good for one either—trying to imagine. He had taken a high seat amongst the devils of the land—I mean literally. You can’t understand. How could you?—with solid pavement under your feet
column29: surrounded by kind neighbours ready to cheer you or to fall on you
column30: stepping delicately between the butcher and the policeman
column31: in the holy terror of scandal and gallows and lunatic asylums—how can you imagine what particular region of the first ages a man’s untrammelled feet may take him into by the way of solitude—utter solitude without a policeman—by the way of silence—utter silence
column32: where no warning voice of a kind neighbour can be heard whispering of public opinion? These little things make all the great difference. When they are gone you must fall back upon your own innate strength
column33: upon your own capacity for faithfulness. Of course you may be too much of a fool to go wrong—too dull even to know you are being assaulted by the powers of darkness. I take it
column34: no fool ever made a bargain for his soul with the devil: the fool is too much of a fool
column35: or the devil too much of a devil—I don’t know which. Or you may be such a thunderingly exalted creature as to be altogether deaf and blind to anything but heavenly sights and sounds. Then the earth for you is only a standing place—and whether to be like this is your loss or your gain I won’t pretend to say. But most of us are neither one nor the other. The earth for us is a place to live in
column36: where we must put up with sights
column41: and not be contaminated.e10 And there
column42: don’t you see? your strength comes in
column43: the faith in your ability for the digging of unostentatious holes to bury the stuff in—your power of devotion
column46: back-breaking business. And that’s difficult enough. Mind
column47: I am not trying to excuse or even explain—I am trying to account to myself for—for—Mr Kurtz—for the shade of Mr Kurtz. This initiated wraith from the back of Nowhere honoured me with its amazing confidence before it vanished altogether. This was because it could speak English to me. The original Kurtz had been educated partly in England
column48: and—as he was good enough to say himself—his sympathies were in the right place. His mother was half-English
column49: his father was half-French.20 All Europe contributed to the making of Kurtz; and by and bye I learned that
column51: the International Society for the Suppression of Savage Customs21 had entrusted him with the making of a report
column52: for its future guidance. And he had written it too. I’ve seen it. I’ve read it. It was eloquent
column55: I think. Seventeen pages of close writing he had found time for! But this must have been before his—let us say—nerves
column57: and caused him to preside at certain midnight dances ending with unspeakable rites
column58: which—as far as I reluctantly gathered from what I heard at various times—were offered up to him—do you understand?—to Mr Kurtz himself. But it was a beautiful piece of writing. The opening paragraph
column60: in the light of later information
column61: strikes me now as ominous. He began with the argument that we whites
column62: from the point of development we had arrived at
column63: ‘must necessarily appear to them [savages] in the nature of supernatural beings—we approach them with the might as of a deity
column65: and so on. ‘By the simple exercise of our will we can exert a power for good practically unbounded
column67: etc.e11 From that point he soared and took me with him. The peroration was magnificent
column69: you know. It gave me the notion of an exotic Immensity ruled by an august Benevolence. It made me tingle with enthusiasm. This was the unbounded power of eloquence—of words—of burning noble words. There were no practical hints to interrupt the magic current of phrases
column70: unless a kind of note at the foot of the last page
column73: may be regarded as the exposition of a method. It was very simple
column74: and at the end of that moving appeal to every altruistic sentiment it blazed at you
column76: like a flash of lightning in a serene sky: ‘Exterminate all the brutes!’22 The curious part was that he had apparently forgotten all about that valuable postscriptum
column79: when he in a sense came to himself
column80: he repeatedly entreated me to take good care of ‘my pamphlet’ (he called it)
column81: as it was sure to have in the future a good influence upon his career. I had full information about all these things
column85: I was to have the care of his memory. I’ve done enough for it to give me the indisputable right to lay it
column87: for an everlasting rest in the dust-bin of progress
column90: all the dead cats of civilisation. But then
column92: I can’t choose. He won’t be forgotten. Whatever he was
column93: he was not common. He had the power to charm or frighten rudimentary souls into an aggravated witch-dance in his honour; he could also fill the small souls of the pilgrims with bitter misgivings:e12 he had one devoted friend at least
column94: and he had conquered one soul in the world that was neither rudimentary nor tainted with self-seeking. No; I can’t forget him
column95: though I am not prepared to affirm the fellow was exactly worth the life we lost in getting to him. I missed my late helmsman awfully—I missed him even while his body was still lying in the pilot-house. Perhaps you will think it passing strange this regret for a savage who was no more account than a grain of sand in a black Sahara. Well
column98: he had steered; for months I had him at my back—a help—an instrument. It was a kind of partnership. He steered for me—I had to look after him
column100: and thus a subtle bond had been created
column101: of which I only became aware when it was suddenly broken. And the intimate profundity of that look he gave me when he received his hurt remains to this day in my memory—like a claim of distant kinship affirmed in a supreme moment."|"Heart of Darkness and the Congo Diary"|"Joseph Conrad"

column1: > 00:00|"shortly after midnight"|"“When I woke up shortly after midnight his warning came to my mind with its hint of danger that seemed
column3: real enough to make me get up for the purpose of having a look round. On the hill a big fire burned
column4: illuminating fitfully a crooked corner of the station-house. One of the agents with a picket of a few of our blacks
column6: was keeping guard over the ivory; but deep within the forest
column8: that seemed to sink and rise from the ground amongst confused columnar shapes of intense blackness
column9: showed the exact position of the camp where Mr Kurtz’s adorers were keeping their uneasy vigil. The monotonous beating of a big drum filled the air with muffled shocks and a lingering vibration. A steady droning sound of many men chanting each to himself some weird incantation came out from the black
column10: flat wall of the woods as the humming of bees comes out of a hive
column11: and had a strange narcotic effect upon my half-awake senses. I believe I dozed off leaning over the rail
column12: till an abrupt burst of yells
column13: an overwhelming outbreak of a pent-up and mysterious frenzy
column14: woke me up in a bewildered wonder. It was cut short all at once
column15: and the low droning went on with an effect of audible and soothing silence. I glanced casually into the little cabin. A light was burning within
column16: but Mr Kurtz was not there."|"Heart of Darkness and the Congo Diary"|"Joseph Conrad"

column1: 12:00|noon|"“When next day we left at noon
column3: of whose presence behind the curtain of trees I had been acutely conscious all the time
column4: flowed out of the woods again
column6: covered the slope with a mass of naked
column8: quivering bronze bodies. I steamed up a bit
column10: and two thousand eyes followed the evolutions of the splashing
column12: fiery river-demon beating the water with its terrible tail and breathing black smoke into the air.e6 In front of the first rank
column15: plastered with bright red earth from head to foot
column16: strutted to and fro restlessly. When we came abreast again
column20: swayed their scarlet bodies; they shook towards the fierce river-demon a bunch of black feathers
column21: a mangy skin with a pendant tail—something that looked like a dried gourd; they shouted periodically together strings of amazing words that resembled no sounds of human language; and the deep murmurs of the crowd
column23: were like the responses of some satanic litany."|"Heart of Darkness and the Congo Diary"|"Joseph Conrad"

column1: ap 09:30|9.30|"Started at 5h 30 after a sleepless night. Country more open–Gently andulating15 hills. Road good in perfect order. (District of Lukungu). Great market at 9.30. bought eggs & chickens–"|"Heart of Darkness and the Congo Diary"|"Joseph Conrad"

06:00|6am|"Left at 6am. after a good night’s rest. Crossed a low range of hills and entered a broad valley or rather plain with a break in the middle–Met an off[ic]er of the State inspecting. A few minutes afterwards saw at a camp[in]g place the dead body of a Backongo.17 Shot? Horrid smell.–Crossed a range of mountains running NW-SE. by a low pass. Another broad flat valley with a deep ravine through the centre.–Clay and gravel. Another range parallel to the first-mentioned with a chain of low foothills running close to it. Between the two came to camp on the banks of the Luinzono River. Camp[in]g place clean. River clear. Gov[ernmen]t Zanzibari18 with register. Canoe. 2 Danes camp[in]g on the other bank.–Health good."|"Heart of Darkness and the Congo Diary"|"Joseph Conrad"

09:00|9am|"Bird notes charming–One especially a flute-like note. Another kind of ‘boom’ ressembling22 the very distant baying of a hound.–Saw only pigeons and a few green parroquets; very small and not many. No birds of prey seen by me. Up to 9am–sky clouded and calm–Afterwards gentle breeze from the N[or]th generally and sky clearing–Nights damp and cool.–White mists on the hills up about halfway. Water effects
column2: very beautiful this morning. Mists generally raising before sky clears."|"Heart of Darkness and the Congo Diary"|"Joseph Conrad"

column1: At 10h passed R. Lukanga and at 10.30 camped on the Mpwe R.
[Sketch: ‘Today’ smarch.’ Beneath title: ‘Direction NNE½N Dist[a]nce 13 miles.’ Marked on sketch: ‘Luinzono
column2: Camp.’]"|"Heart of Darkness and the Congo Diary"|"Joseph Conrad"

even cold and very damp–Sky densely overcast. Gentle breeze from NE. Road through a narrow plain up to R. Kwilu. Swift flowing and deep 50 yds wide–Passed in canoes–After[war]ds up and down very steep hills intersected by deep ravines–Main chain of heights running mostly NW-SE or W and E at times. Stopped at Manyamba."|"Heart of Darkness and the Congo Diary"|"Joseph Conrad"

column1: 12:00|noon|"Left very early–Road ascending all the time.–Passed villages. Country seems thickly inhabited. At 11h arrived at large Market place. Left at noon and camped at 1h pm."|"Heart of Darkness and the Congo Diary"|"Joseph Conrad"
08:00|"8 am"|"[Untitled sketch of day’s journey marked: ‘Mafiela
column7: camp.’ Underneath: ‘General direction E½N ← W½S. / Sun visible at 8 am. Very hot / distance–18 miles.’]"|"Heart of Darkness and the Congo Diary"|"Joseph Conrad"

column1: Sun visible at 6.30. Very warm day.–
|Heart of Darkness and the Congo Diary"|"Joseph Conrad"

06:00|"6 am"|"Left at 6 am intending to camp at Kinfumu–Two hours sharp walk brought me to Nsona na Nsefe–Market–½ hour after Harou arrived very ill with billious [sic] attack and fever.–Laid him down in gov[ernmen]t shimbek–Dose of Ipeca.34 Vomiting bile in enormous quantities. At 11h gave him 1 gramme of quinine and lots of hot tea. Hot fit ending in heavy perspiration. At 9h p.m. put him in hammock and started for Kinfumu–Row with carriers35 all the way. Harou suffering much through the jerks of the hammock. Camped at a small stream.–"|"Heart of Darkness and the Congo Diary"|"Joseph Conrad"

column2: sky clouded and strong NW wind very chilling. From 1h pm to 4h pm sky clear and very hot day. Expect lots of battles with carriers to-morrow–Had them all called and made a speech which they did not understand.36 They promise good behaviour"|"Heart of Darkness and the Congo Diary"|"Joseph Conrad"

column1: 14:30|"2.30 pm"|"At 2.30 pm reached Luila at last and camped on right bank.–Breeze from SW"|"Heart of Darkness and the Congo Diary"|"Joseph Conrad"
06:30|"6.30 am"|"Left at 6.30 am after a very indifferently passed night–Cold
column2: Heavy mists–Road in long ascents and sharp dips all the way to Mfumu Mbé–"|"Heart of Darkness and the Congo Diary"|"Joseph Conrad"

column1: 12:30|12.30pm|"Left at 12.30pm–towards Nselemba. Many ascents–The aspect of the country entirely changed–Wooded hills with openings.–Path almost all the afternoon thro[ugh] a forest of light trees with dense undergrowth.–"|"Heart of Darkness and the Congo Diary"|"Joseph Conrad"
